elements.content: Oxygen-involved electrocatalytic processes, including the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), are central to a series of advanced modern energy and conversion technologies, such as water electrolyzers, fuel cells, and CO2 reduction or N2 fixation devices. A comprehensive and in-depth understanding of the charge transfer and energy conversion process that ubiquitously occurs over solid–liquid electrochemical interfaces during oxygen electrocatalysis is crucial for understanding the key essence of oxygen-related electrochemistry. The huge challenges for dynamic studies over solid–liquid interfaces during oxygen electrocatalysis lie in the all-embracing electrochemical processes of the catalytic reactions, associated with both structural and reactive intermediates evolution on the electrode surface, and in the significant influence of the aqueous environments of electrolytes used. Hence, overcoming these challenges intrinsically calls for a great cooperation of multiple cutting-edge in situ technologies. Synchrotron radiation (SR) X-ray absorption fine structure (SR-XAFS) spectroscopy is highly sensitive to the local atomic structure of nanomaterials, and SR-based Fourier transform infrared (SR-FTIR) spectroscopy features unique molecular fingerprint identification to determine active species on the surface of electrodes. One can imagine that the correlative in situ SR-XAFS/FTIR spectroscopic investigations will potentially provide sufficient, reliable, and complementary information at the atomic/molecular level to depict vivid and comprehensive “dynamic movies” of solid–liquid electrochemical interfaces during oxygen electrocatalysis, which will help effectively promote/simplify the complicated screening process of advanced oxygen electrocatalysts for efficient high-energy-density energy systems.

elements.content: In this Account, starting with some fundamentals of SR-based spectroscopic technologies, tips for obtaining high-quality SR-XAFS and SR-FTIR spectroscopy results during the electrocatalytic process are comprehensively specified. Subsequently, the latest research achievements of dynamic investigations mainly from our group based on in situ SR-XAFS and/or SR-FTIR spectroscopies will be systematically scrutinized and properly emphasized in detail, where the currently attractive metal–organic–framework (MOF) nanomaterials and single-atom catalysts (SACs) are selected as the main object of research. Moreover, the vital contributions of correlative in situ SR-XAFS/FTIR studies on new discoveries of the dynamic evolution of solid–liquid interfaces during oxygen electrocatalysis are highlighted. In particular, our pioneering research found that the potential-dependent dynamically coupled oxygen formed in the precatalytic stage was a very useful promoter in SACs to promote efficient OER kinetics under acidic conditions. In addition, the in situ generated metastable Ni1–N2 centers with more structural degrees of freedom in SACs could potentially facilitate the fast 4e– ORR kinetics. This Account is anticipated to stimulate broad interest in dynamic explorations in various catalytic processes of interest in the material science and electrochemistry communities using correlative SR-based technologies.

Introduction

The development of advanced energy conversion devices, such as fuel cells and water electrolyzers, is of essential importance for the great blossoming of the modern green and sustainable energy industry. To carry forward the practical deployment of these energy systems, the requirements of active electrocatalysts with high activity and robust long-term durability should be satisfied for efficient fuel cells and water electrolyzers. Oxygen electrocatalytic reactions, including the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), occur at the solid-liquid electrochemical interfaces of catalytic electrodes and greatly affect the overall efficiency and operational durability of industrial fuel cells and water electrolyzers due to their intrinsically sluggish kinetics. Therefore, it is very significant to completely understand the essential dynamics of solid-liquid electrochemical interfaces during electrocatalysis to rationally design, synthesize, and screen advanced oxygen electrocatalysts.

elements.content: During oxygen electrocatalysis, the surface rearrangement of electrocatalysts has been commonly predicted in theoretical calculations and evidently observed in experiments. Accompanied by surface reconstruction, a series of oxo intermediates, such as *OH, *O, *OOH, etc., successively appears over the evolved active sites of electrocatalysts during the catalytic process. To gain a full picture of the catalytic dynamics, the evolution of both surface structures and reactive intermediates over the solid–liquid interface of electrodes is recommended to be concurrently monitored, but it faces a great challenge because of the complication of the electrode surface and limitation of effective detection technologies in aqueous environments.

elements.content: The worldwide blossoming of synchrotron radiation (SR) facilities provides a promising and high-brilliance light source to rapidly develop SR-based spectroscopic technologies toward surficial/interfacial detection in aqueous conditions. In particular, SR-based X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (SR-XAFS), which has element specificity, high local structure sensitivity, and a strong penetration capability in aqueous solutions, is a very powerful tool to promptly probe the structural evolution of active metal centers in electrocatalysts under working conditions. Moreover, SR-based Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (SR-FTIR), with molecular fingerprint identification of surface species, can successfully track the evolution of reactive intermediates on the surface of electrodes during electrocatalytic processes. A full picture of the dynamic evolution over the solid–liquid interfaces may be depicted by correlative in situ SR-XAFS/FTIR analyses. Indeed, certain pioneering works based on in situ SR-XAFS and/or SR-FTIR investigations have been implemented to disclose the catalytic mechanism of catalysts in various important chemical reactions. Using correlative in situ SR-XAFS and SR-FTIR technologies, some interesting discoveries were originally reported by our group, which dominantly focused on the intriguing OER/ORR, urea synthesis, CO2 reduction, and nitrogen fixation reactions. However, the exploitation of correlative SR-XAFS and SR-FTIR spectroscopies on dynamics investigations remains in the infant stage. To speed up the coupling of SR-XAFS and SR-FTIR spectroscopic techniques, it is necessary to systematically scrutinize recent significant achievements of in situ SR-XAFS and/or SR-FTIR investigations during electrocatalysis.

elements.content: In the 1970s, the advent of the first SR sources with bending magnets successfully triggered the rapid development of SR-XAFS as a useful tool for quantitative structure detection. As shown in a, when an incident X-ray photon with suitable energy is absorbed by central atom A during SR-XAFS measurements, an outgoing core-level photoelectron wave will be promptly produced. This outgoing photoelectron wave can be scattered by the surrounding atoms in the first and second shells, e.g., the B and C atoms, and then return to the initial central atom A. This interference between incident X-ray photons and returned photoelectron waves can contribute to an oscillatory structure in the X-ray absorption coefficient, which is the origin of XAFS. In terms of the energy region in XAFS spectroscopy, the region from the absorption edge to 30–50 eV above it is referred to as the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), while the region from 30 to 50 eV above the adsorption edge to 1000 eV or more is usually called the extended XAFS (EXAFS). In contrast to XANES, the EXAFS region is dominantly affected by the single-scattering process of the photoelectrons. Therefore, it is much easier to extract useful structural information on the bond length, coordination number, and structural disorder degree around the central atom A by analyzing the EXAFS spectra (a) due to its short-range-order effect. As two important EXAFS data processing methods, Fourier transform EXAFS (FT-EXAFS) analyses could separate the contributions of different shells around the central atom in the R space directly while wavelet transform EXAFS (WT-EXAFS) results could discern the contribution of each single/scattering pathway in both R space and k space at the same time. Beyond the adsorption edge, the magnitudes of the XAFS oscillatory curves are generally on the order of 10–2 of that at the adsorption edge. Thus, several aspects must be considered to collect high-quality XAFS data, such as the X-ray source, detector and detection modes, and sample preparations.

elements.content: During SR-XAFS measurements, both transmission and fluorescence detection modes are frequently used, where X-ray absorption of samples in the transmission detection mode can be determined by the incident and transmitted beam intensity while the generated X-ray fluorescence intensity in the fluorescence detection mode provides another measure for X-ray absorption of samples. For practical applications of SR-XAFS detection in dynamic exploration, the back-incident fluorescence SR-XAFS mode coupled with a well-designed in situ cell is generally used to avoid the influence of aqueous electrolytes (b). To acquire high-quality XAFS data in the practical fluorescence SR-XAFS measurements, two aspects must be considered: decreasing the stray absorption and scattering of incident X-ray photons and increasing the outgoing fluorescence signals of interest. To reduce the additional loss of incident X-ray photon flux, Kapton film or Si3N4 substrate, which is insensitive to X-ray photons, is commonly employed as the X-ray window of the in situ cells. Moreover, the as-prepared working electrodes are always placed very close to the X-ray window of the homemade in situ cells to effectively decrease the loss of X-ray photon flux (b). To increase the desirable fluorescence signals, the mass loading of catalysts on the working electrodes needs to be optimized before in situ SR-XAFS measurements begin, which is highly associated with the atomic number and fluorescence yield of the absorbed central metal atom of catalysts. Depending on various catalytic systems, a catalyst mass loading range of 0.2–2 mg cm–2 on the working electrodes may be suitable for in situ fluorescence SR-XAFS measurements based on previous reports and our practical experience.

elements.content: It is well known that usually only the surface of the catalyst participates in the catalysis, whereas the bulk of the material is more or less inert. Hence, in addition to high-quality SR-XAFS spectroscopy, the proportion of surface signals in the total recorded XAFS data must be maximized to identify the exact structural evolution of the surface active sites during electrocatalytic reactions. From the technical viewpoint, the enhancement of the incident X-ray angle is substantially helpful to shorten the detection depth on the surface of the electrodes. From a synthetic viewpoint, the maximal ratio of surface sites to bulk sites in targeted catalysts is an effective approach to obtain sufficient changed XAFS signals of the actual surface dynamic evolution of electrodes. To this end, functional nanomaterials with highly exposed metal sites and well-designed architectures, such as MOF nanoarrays and three-dimensional (3D) porous SACs, are carefully selected as promising model catalysts in our group for dynamic studies. Furthermore, a 3 or 6 μm thick metal foil, which is composed of the Z −1 element (Z is the atomic number for the central atom), is often employed as a filter to suppress the elastic and inelastic scattering signals and other fluorescence counts of noninterest during practical SR-XAFS tests, as indicated in b.

elements.content: As classical vibrational techniques, both Raman and IR spectroscopies are usually employed for effectively probing vibration in electrocatalysts during electrocatalysis. Relative to the light-scattering mechanism of Raman spectroscopy, SR-FTIR spectroscopy, in principle, is based on the interference of IR radiation and surface active molecules/groups. Two dominant modes of molecular vibrations are observed for the surface active molecules/groups in the mid-IR region of SR-FTIR spectroscopy (approximately 350–4000 cm–1), the stretching mode and the bending mode, which involve symmetric and asymmetric stretching in the plane and wagging, rocking, twisting, and scissoring bending out of the plane (a). There are two main typical regions in the mid-IR range: the fingerprint region and the functional group region, which are associated with the wavenumber ranges of 350–1500 and 1500–4000 cm–1, respectively. With fingerprint features and high surface sensitivity, SR-FTIR spectroscopy can provide detailed information to qualitatively/semiquantitatively identify the nature of key surface species at the electrochemical interfaces of electrodes during oxygen electrocatalysis.

elements.content: In general, SR-FTIR spectroscopy can be utilized in both transmission mode and reflection mode. In particular, the reactive intermediates during oxygen electrocatalysis mainly contribute to special IR adsorption bands in the wavenumber ranges of 800–1500 (oxygen-related species) and 3000–4000 cm–2 (hydrogen-related species), which fully overlap with the strong IR absorption areas of water molecules. Therefore, a reflection mode of FTIR spectroscopy coupled with a well-designed homemade in situ cell is considered more effective and practical for the dynamic studies under aqueous environments. As depicted in b, a single-reflection SR-FTIR method was developed by our group to effectively monitor the dynamics over solid–liquid interfaces of electrodes during electrocatalysis, where the incident SR-IR light is directly reflected on the surface of the working electrode and then recorded by the mercury–cadmium–telluride (MCT) detector on the same side. To minimize the influence of water molecules, the catalysts coated on the glass carbon substrate are held very close to the ZnSe film of the IR window in in situ cells, where a micrometer-scale water film (usually 5–10 μm) over the surface of the sample is obtained due to the capillarity permeation effect. Moreover, to mitigate the mass transport issues, electrolyte circulation via peristaltic pumps is usually required during SR-FTIR measurements.

elements.content: To obtain a full picture of the dynamics over solid–liquid interfaces, multiple cutting-edge technologies must be integrated. As mentioned above, SR-XAFS spectroscopy with high local structure sensitivity is undoubtedly considered a powerful tool to atomically explore the structural changes of catalysts during oxygen electrocatalytic reactions. As two attractive noninvasive spectroscopic techniques, the correlative SR-XAFS and SR-FTIR studies can potentially provide complementary information on the structure and surface species evolution over the solid–liquid interfaces of electrodes under realistic working conditions, as illustrated in . elements.content: To perform relevant dynamic studies, the key point is to make the electrochemical environments of the working electrodes as consistent/similar as possible when correlative SR-XAFS and SR-FTIR data are recorded. In such cases, the acquired SR-XAFS and SR-FTIR spectroscopies can exactly reflect similar reactive kinetics over the solid–liquid interfaces of electrocatalysts. To achieve this goal, preliminary electrochemical measurements such as linear sweep voltammetry, cycle voltammetry, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy should be performed in both the SR-XAFS and the SR-FTIR in situ cells to ensure the similarity of the electrochemical conditions and rationally select suitable measurement parameters for subsequent in situ explorations. Normally, the SR-XAFS or SR-FTIR spectra are recorded by our group at six different situations during oxygen electrocatalysis: in the air without solutions, soaking in the solution without applied potentials, at the open-circuit voltage (OCV), at the onset potential (corresponding to a current density of 0.1 mA cm–2), at potentials relative to a current density of 1 mA cm–2 for the OER or at the half-wave potential for the ORR, and at potentials relative to the highly efficient catalytic stage for the OER or relative to the limiting current density for the ORR.

elements.content: Transition-metal-based MOF nanomaterials have been considered promising oxygen electrocatalysts, but the nature of their active phase and the underlying catalytic mechanism remain elusive. Recently, using in situ SR-XAFS spectroscopy, we atomically monitored the structural transformation ofa bromine-confined Ni–MOF (Br–Ni–MOF) during the OER process in alkaline solution (). Under a low potential of 1.10 V, a great promotion in intensity for both the Ni–O and the Ni–Ni peaks is found in the FT-EXAFS curves of Br–Ni-MOF relative to the ex situ spectrum (a and b). Using WT-EXAFS analysis (c), this structural change can be well assigned to the formation of a β-type Ni­(OH)2 analog for Br–Ni-MOF in the resting state. Furthermore, at 1.45 or 1.55 V, substantial blue shifts of the Ni–O and Ni–Ni peaks are observed (by approximately 0.19 and 0.31 Å, respectively) relative to those at 1.10 V, which are accompanied by a shift of the corresponding Ni adsorption edge to the high-energy side (d and e). A full comparison with the detailed structures of Ni-based oxyhydroxides confirmed the post formation of the γ-NiOOH analog in the catalytic stage for Br–Ni–MOF. Accordingly, a successive two-step reconstruction of Br–Ni-MOF from a pristine MOF structure to a hydroxide analog and subsequently to an oxyhydroxide analog is uncovered during the OER (f), which is similar to the in situ observations of the active NiCo–MOF-74 during the OER reported by Tang’s group.

elements.content: In addition to the determination of the active phase, the real active site of the catalysts during electrocatalysis should be identified to disclose their underlying structure–activity relationship. SACs with well-dispersed isolated metal sites offer an incredible opportunity to clearly identify the working mechanism of real active sites in nanomaterials during oxygen electrocatalysis. On the basis of in situ SR-XAFS spectroscopy, we obtained meaningful insights into the electronic and atomic structure evolution of isolated Cu sites in unsymmetrically coordinated Cu–S1N3 SACs during the ORR process (). Upon the applied potential decreasing from 1.05 to 0.75 V, a shift of the absorption edge position toward the lower energy side is observed in the Cu K-edge XANES spectra, which indicates a reduced valence state from approximately 2+ to 1+ for the Cu species in Cu–S1N3 SACs (a and b). Notably, these reduced Cu (1+) sites can be restored to Cu (2+) when the applied potential is returned to 1.05 V, which suggests that the postformed Cu (1+) sites served as reversible active metal centers for the ORR. As illustrated in c, the dominant peak of the Cu–N/S bonds in the Cu K-edge FT-EXAFS curves shows a substantial shift to the low-R direction, from 1.55 to 1.49 Å, under reductive potentials of 0.90 or 0.75 V. The corresponding XAFS fitting results further confirmed that the initial bond length of Cu–N is reduced from the initial 1.98 to 1.94 Å at 0.9 V and subsequently to 1.93 Å at 0.75 V with the nearly unchanged bond length of 2.32 Å for Cu–S bonds. In combination with DFT calculations, these low-valence Cu (1+) centers with shrinking Cu–N bonds can promote the generation of *OOH, *O, and *OH intermediates over Cu–S1N3 centers for efficient 4e– ORR kinetics (d).

elements.content: The exploration of intermediate evolution over active sites of electrocatalysts is very important for understanding their underlying electrocatalytic mechanism. To this end, we adopted in situ SR-FTIR spectroscopy to study the surface species evolution over the solid–liquid interface of transition-metal-based SACs during acidic OER electrocatalysis (). A unique type of hetero-N-coordinated Co-based SAC (HNC–Co SAC) was used as an ideal OER model catalyst for in situ SR-FTIR investigation. When a potential of >1.38 V was applied, a new absorption band appeared at approximately 1248 cm–1 for the HNC–Co catalysts (a), which is assigned to the formation of key *O intermediates over Co active sites. Moreover, the intensity of the vibrational band of 1248 cm–1 gradually strengthened with increasing potential, and there was a potential-dependent red shift of the Co–N absorption bands from 1048 to 978 cm–1 (b and c). This result hints that during the OER process the potential-driven electron transfer from the isolated Co sites to the adjacent N atoms could effectively facilitate the appearance of key *O intermediates over Co sites of HNC–Co catalysts and form active H2N–(*O–Co)–N4 moieties for efficient 4e– OER kinetics. By combining this information with the DFT calculations, it is unraveled that the active H2N–(*O–Co)–N4 moieties play a key role in promoting the O–O coupling during the acidic OER process (d).

In particular, the emerging cutting-edge space-resolved and/or time-resolved SR-XAFS/FTIR spectroscopies will provide sharper insights into the dynamic evolution of the electrocatalysts during the interesting electrocatalytic process in a micrometer zone and/or at a microsecond/subnanosecond time scale, which can be a very significant and powerful approach to dissect the underlying fast dynamic process of catalysts in the fields of material science and electrochemistry.

In addition to the determination of the active phase, the real active site of the catalysts during electrocatalysis should be identified to disclose their underlying structure–activity relationship. SACs with well-dispersed isolated metal sites offer an incredible opportunity to clearly identify the working mechanism of real active sites in nanomaterials during oxygen electrocatalysis. On the basis of in situ SR-XAFS spectroscopy, we obtained meaningful insights into the electronic and atomic structure evolution of isolated Cu sites in unsymmetrically coordinated Cu–S1N3 SACs during the ORR process (). Upon the applied potential decreasing from 1.05 to 0.75 V, a shift of the absorption edge position toward the lower energy side is observed in the Cu K-edge XANES spectra, which indicates a reduced valence state from approximately 2+ to 1+ for the Cu species in Cu–S1N3 SACs (a and b). Notably, these reduced Cu (1+) sites can be restored to Cu (2+) when the applied potential is returned to 1.05 V, which suggests that the postformed Cu (1+) sites served as reversible active metal centers for the ORR. As illustrated in c, the dominant peak of the Cu–N/S bonds in the Cu K-edge FT-EXAFS curves shows a substantial shift to the low-R direction, from 1.55 to 1.49 Å, under reductive potentials of 0.90 or 0.75 V. The corresponding XAFS fitting results further confirmed that the initial bond length of Cu–N is reduced from the initial 1.98 to 1.94 Å at 0.9 V and subsequently to 1.93 Å at 0.75 V with the nearly unchanged bond length of 2.32 Å for Cu–S bonds. In combination with DFT calculations, these low-valence Cu (1+) centers with shrinking Cu–N bonds can promote the generation of *OOH, *O, and *OH intermediates over Cu–S1N3 centers for efficient 4e– ORR kinetics (d).

Tracking Species Evolution by In Situ SR-FTIR Spectroscopy

The exploration of intermediate evolution over active sites of electrocatalysts is very important for understanding their underlying electrocatalytic mechanism. To this end, we adopted in situ SR-FTIR spectroscopy to study the surface species evolution over the solid–liquid interface of transition-metal-based SACs during acidic OER electrocatalysis (). A unique type of hetero-N-coordinated Co-based SAC (HNC–Co SAC) was used as an ideal OER model catalyst for in situ SR-FTIR investigation. When a potential of >1.38 V was applied, a new absorption band appeared at approximately 1248 cm–1 for the HNC–Co catalysts (a), which is assigned to the formation of key *O intermediates over Co active sites. Moreover, the intensity of the vibrational band of 1248 cm–1 gradually strengthened with increasing potential, and there was a potential-dependent red shift of the Co–N absorption bands from 1048 to 978 cm–1 (b and c). This result hints that during the OER process the potential-driven electron transfer from the isolated Co sites to the adjacent N atoms could effectively facilitate the appearance of key *O intermediates over Co sites of HNC–Co catalysts and form active H2N–(*O–Co)–N4 moieties for efficient 4e– OER kinetics. By combining this information with the DFT calculations, it is unraveled that the active H2N–(*O–Co)–N4 moieties play a key role in promoting the O–O coupling during the acidic OER process (d).

Dynamic Studies Based on Correlative SR-XAFS/FTIR Spectroscopy

Correlative in situ detection by SR-XAFS/FTIR spectroscopy opens up a unique approach to bridge the structural changes of active sites with the concomitant intermediation evolution for oxygen dynamic studies. Recently, we promptly probed the dynamic evolution of isolated Ir sites in heteronitrogen-configured Ir-based SACs using correlative SR-XAFS and SR-FTIR spectroscopies. Under a potential of 1.25 V, an enhanced peak intensity of the white-line peak and the nearest Ir–N/O coordination shell is clearly discerned in relation to that at the ex situ states (a and b). The corresponding XAFS fitting analyses subsequently assign this enhanced peak intensity at 1.25 V to a newly formed Ir–O bond over Ir sites in the precatalytic stage in addition to the initial square-planar Ir1–N4 configurations. Upon reaching the increased potentials of 1.35 and 1.45 V, the intensity for the nearest Ir–N/O peak is enhanced with the first red shift (at 1.35 V) and subsequent blue shift (at 1.45 V) of the Ir–N/O peak position relative to that at 1.25 V (b). Quantitatively, the XAFS fitting analyses reveal that the coordination number of Ir–O bonds for the isolated Ir centers is increased to 2 at 1.35 V compared with the only Ir–O bond at 1.25 V. This result may indicate the further formation of key oxo intermediates over Ir centers of Ir-based SACs in the catalytic stage.
